TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit SplitterEventArgs extends System.EventArgs

Docs.summary: Provides data for and the events.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> event occurs when the user is moving the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> event occurs when the user finishes moving the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs> class specifies the position of the mouse pointer and the position of the upper-left corner of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this type. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoved> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer> named `SplitContainer1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoved> event.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#548](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/CS/EventExamples.cs#548)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#548](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/VB/EventExamples.vb#548)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this property along with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs.SplitY%2A> property of this class to determine the position of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter> control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> events are raised.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoved?displayProperty=nameWithType> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer> named `SplitContainer1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoved?displayProperty=nameWithType> event.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#548](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/CS/EventExamples.cs#548)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#548](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/VB/EventExamples.vb#548)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this property along with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitterEventArgs.Y%2A> property of this class to determine the current location of the mouse pointer when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoving> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Splitter.SplitterMoved> events are raised.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoved?displayProperty=nameWithType> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer> named `SplitContainer1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.SplitContainer.SplitterMoved?displayProperty=nameWithType> event.
